Title: American Modernism (POETRY)
Content:
Thomas Stearns Eliot - (1888 - 1965)

He was a Poet, dramatist, literary critic, and editor. 

  • 1888 - Born in St. Louis, Missouri
  • studied at Milton Academy, Harvard University, the Sorbonne and Merton College at Oxford
  • 1917 - Prufrock and Other Observations
  • 1920 - Poems
  • 1922 - The Waste Land
  • 1932 - Eliot arranged a formal separation from Vivien, his wife
  • 1948 - won Nobel Prize for Literature
  • Eliot did not remarry until 1958, his seventieth year, and he seems to have been supremely happy in these last years with Valerie Eliot
  • dies in 1965 

 literary characteristics: 

  • In ithe poem "Prufrock", Eliot may be said to have invented modernism.
  • major symbols including the waste land, water, city, stairs, journey; the themes of time, death, rebirth, love; the quest motif on psychological, metaphysical, esthetic levels and the poet's admiration of Dante.
  • Four Quartets (poems Bumt Norton, East Coker, The Dry Salvages, Little Giddig) are regarded as Eliot's culminating achievement, appropriately recognized by the Nobel Prize in 1948
